name: MIT License
short_description: A short, permissive software license allowing extensive reuse.
description: The MIT License is a permissive free software license originating at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). It allows reuse within proprietary software provided all copies of the licensed software include a copy of the MIT License terms and the copyright notice. It's known for its simplicity and broad compatibility.
compatibility_notes: Highly compatible with most other licenses, including proprietary ones.
recommended_use_cases: Simple, permissive open-source projects
Libraries and frameworks
Projects where maximum reuse is desired, including in proprietary software.

name: Apache License 2.0
short_description: A permissive license with explicit patent grants.
description: The Apache License 2.0 is a permissive free software license from the Apache Software Foundation. It allows users to freely use, modify, and distribute the software. A key feature is its explicit grant of patent rights from contributors to users, protecting against patent litigation.
compatibility_notes: Compatible with GPLv3 (one-way), but not GPLv2. Generally compatible with proprietary software.
recommended_use_cases: Enterprise software
Projects requiring explicit patent grants
Large collaborative projects where patent clarity is important.

name: GNU General Public License v3.0
short_description: Strong copyleft license requiring derivatives to remain open.
description: The GNU General Public License v3.0 is a strong copyleft license that ensures software and its derivatives remain free and open. Any redistribution of the software, even if modified, must be under the same license. This prevents proprietary appropriation of the software.
compatibility_notes: Incompatible with many permissive licenses if combined. Compatible with Apache 2.0.
recommended_use_cases: Projects where keeping all derivatives open source is critical
Software freedom advocacy
Applications where ensuring user freedom is paramount.

name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0
short_description: Strongest copyleft license, applies copyleft over networks.
description: The GNU Affero General Public License v3.0 is a strong copyleft license that closes the 'ASP loophole'. It ensures that if you run a modified version of the software on a server and allow others to interact with it over a network, you must offer them the source code of your modified version.
key_features: Network Use as Distribution (ASP Loophole closed)
compatibility_notes: Generally compatible with GPLv3. Less compatible than GPLv3 due to network clause.
recommended_use_cases: Web applications
SaaS (Software as a Service) projects where you want to ensure any deployed modifications are also open source.

name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0
short_description: Weak copyleft license for libraries, allowing proprietary linking.
description: The GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0 is a weaker copyleft license primarily intended for software libraries. It allows linking with proprietary software but requires any modifications to the library itself to be open source and licensed under the LGPL.
compatibility_notes: More compatible with proprietary software than GPL. Compatible with GPLv3.
recommended_use_cases: Software libraries intended for use in both open and closed-source applications.
Components that need wider adoption in commercial products.

name: BSD 3-Clause 'New' or 'Revised' License
short_description: A highly permissive license with minimal restrictions.
description: The BSD 3-Clause License is a permissive free software license. It permits unrestricted redistribution for any purpose as long as its copyright notice and license's disclaimers of warranty are maintained, and the names of the contributors are not used to endorse products derived from the software without specific prior written permission.
compatibility_notes: Highly compatible with most other licenses, including proprietary ones.
recommended_use_cases: Highly permissive open-source projects
Software that may be incorporated into proprietary systems without significant burden.

name: Mozilla Public License 2.0
short_description: Weak copyleft license requiring modifications to files to be open.
description: The Mozilla Public License 2.0 is a weak copyleft license that aims to strike a balance between permissive and strong copyleft licenses. It requires modifications to licensed files to be open source, but allows linking with proprietary files and does not extend its copyleft to the entire derived work.
compatibility_notes: Compatible with GPL and Apache (under certain conditions).
recommended_use_cases: Projects that want a balance between permissiveness and protecting contributions
Cross-platform libraries, especially for browser technologies.

name: CC BY 4.0
short_description: Attribution required; allows commercial use and modifications.
description: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International. This license allows others to distribute, remix, adapt, and build upon your work, even commercially, as long as they credit you for the original creation. It's the most accommodating of CC licenses, aside from CC0.
compatibility_notes: Widely compatible; derivatives can be under any license.
recommended_use_cases: Images
Music
Text
Videos
Any creative work where attribution is the only requirement for reuse, including commercial use.

name: CC BY-SA 4.0
short_description: Attribution and ShareAlike required; allows commercial use.
description: Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International. This license allows others to remix, adapt, and build upon your work, even commercially, as long as they credit you and license their new creations under the identical terms. It's the 'copyleft' of Creative Commons licenses.
compatibility_notes: Derivatives must be under CC BY-SA.
recommended_use_cases: Educational materials
Wikis
Any creative work where you want derivatives to remain openly licensed and shareable.

name: CC BY-NC 4.0
description: Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International. This license allows others to remix, adapt, and build upon your work non-commercially, and although their new works must also acknowledge you and be non-commercial, they don’t have to license their derivative works on the same terms.
compatibility_notes: Derivatives can be under any license, as long as they remain non-commercial.
recommended_use_cases: Personal art projects
Educational content where commercial reuse is not desired.
Content you wish to share broadly but not monetize directly.

name: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0
description: Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International. This license allows others to remix, adapt, and build upon your work non-commercially, as long as they credit you and license their new creations under the identical terms.
compatibility_notes: Derivatives must be under CC BY-NC-SA and remain non-commercial.
recommended_use_cases: Non-commercial educational resources
Community-driven projects where commercial use is restricted and derivatives should also be shared non-commercially.

name: CC BY-ND 4.0
short_description: Attribution required; allows commercial but no derivatives.
description: Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivatives 4.0 International. This license allows for redistribution, commercial and non-commercial, as long as it is passed along unchanged and in whole, with credit to you. No adaptations or modifications are permitted.
compatibility_notes: Cannot be combined with other works if it results in a derivative work.
recommended_use_cases: Official publications
Content where exact integrity is important, even with commercial reuse (e.g., logos, official documents).

name: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0
short_description: Attribution, Non-Commercial, No Derivatives; most restrictive CC.
description: Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International. The most restrictive of the six main Creative Commons licenses, allowing others to download your works and share them with others as long as they credit you, but they can’t change them in any way or use them commercially.
compatibility_notes: Cannot be combined with other works; use is very limited.
recommended_use_cases: Very specific and controlled distribution of original works, e.g., proprietary content with free sharing allowed for personal viewing only.

name: CC0 1.0 Universal (Public Domain Dedication)
short_description: Dedicates work to the public domain, waiving all rights.
description: Creative Commons Zero (CC0) is a public domain dedication that allows creators to waive all copyright and related rights in their works and dedicate them to the public domain. It effectively puts the work into the public domain to the greatest extent possible under law, allowing anyone to use it for any purpose without restriction.
recommended_use_cases: Works you explicitly want to release into the public domain
Data sets
Scientific research where maximum reuse is desired without attribution burdens.

name: Open Font License 1.1 (OFL)
short_description: Free and open source license for fonts, allowing modification and bundling.
description: The SIL Open Font License (OFL) is a free, libre and open source license for fonts. It permits fonts to be used, studied, modified and redistributed freely as long as they are not sold by themselves. It allows font embedding and bundling with software/documents.
compatibility_notes: Specifically designed for fonts; generally compatible with software licenses when fonts are bundled.
recommended_use_cases: Open source fonts
Fonts intended for wide distribution and modification by designers and developers.
Embedding fonts in web pages or applications.

name: Commercial Software License (Example)
short_description: A placeholder for a typical restrictive commercial license.
description: This represents a generic commercial software license. Such licenses are typically highly restrictive, granting only specific, limited rights to the user, often for a fee. Redistribution, modification, and sometimes even commercial use are usually prohibited unless explicitly licensed.
compatibility_notes: Not compatible with open source licenses; designed for closed-source ecosystems.
recommended_use_cases: Proprietary software products sold with a one-time fee or subscription.
Applications where the source code and modification rights are fully retained by the developer.
